file_metadata.title: Ion flow regulates left-right asymmetry in sea urchin development

chunks.text: The degree of conservation among phyla of early mechanisms that pattern the left-right (LR) axis is poorly understood. Sea urchin larvae exhibit consistently oriented LR asymmetry, with the adult rudiment forming from the left coelomic sac (left hydrocoel). This left preference is conserved among echinoderm larvae, but its mechanism is largely unknown. This study investigates the possibility that ion flux mechanisms control asymmetry in sea urchins, similar to vertebrates, using two asymmetrically expressed marker genes, HpNot and HpFoxFQ-like, in Hemicentrotus pulcherrimus. Several ion-transporter inhibitors were screened, and H+/K+-ATPase blockers (omeprazole, lansoprazole, SCH28080) and a calcium ionophore (A23187) altered the normal sidedness of asymmetric gene expression. Omeprazole disrupted consistent adult rudiment formation asymmetry. H+/K+-ATPase-like antigens were present through the blastula stage and exhibited asymmetry, being present in a single blastomere in 32-cell embryos. These results suggest that spatially-regulated early transport of H+, K+, and Ca2+ is involved in establishing LR asymmetry in sea urchin development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion flux, particularly H+, K+, and Ca2+ transport, plays a crucial role in establishing left-right asymmetry in sea urchin development, similar to vertebrates.

chunks.text: Consistent asymmetries of organs are found in many animal phyla. Molecular mechanisms establishing LR asymmetry have been studied in vertebrates, revealing a conserved cascade involving Nodal and Pitx2. However, the initial symmetry-breaking step and early mechanisms are less understood. One model proposes that nodal monocilia propel fluid containing determinants to the left side, potentially involving mechano-sensitive cells and calcium signaling. Alternative mechanisms have been suggested in frogs and chicks. Levin et al. demonstrated that side-specific membrane hyperpolarization by H+/K+-ATPase plays a critical role, possibly by regulating signaling or electrophoretic movement of determinants. Another study suggests Notch signaling activation through localized extracellular calcium elevation induced by H+/K+-ATPase. The evolutionary conservation of these mechanisms and their relevance in invertebrates is debated. Echinoderms, including sea urchins, show LR asymmetry during development. The adult rudiment forms on the left side during the late larval stage. While mechanisms for primary and oral-aboral axes are clearer, the LR axis mechanism remains elusive. Manipulation experiments suggest commitment to left adult rudiment formation from gastrula to prism stages by an influence from the right side.
chunks.chunk_summary: While the molecular mechanisms of left-right asymmetry are being elucidated in vertebrates, the initial symmetry-breaking steps and their conservation in invertebrates, such as echinoderms, remain an open question.

chunks.text: This study investigates the molecular basis of LR asymmetry in sea urchins. A pharmacological screen using ion flux modulators was performed. H,K-ATPase blockers and a calcium ionophore destabilized the normal LR asymmetry of two molecular markers. The localization of H,K-ATPase in early embryos revealed an asymmetric pattern, similar to vertebrates. The results suggest an asymmetrically localized regulation of ion flux involving H+, K+, and Ca2+ from early stages, essential for symmetry breaking. These findings, along with a recent study on Paracentrotus lividus, suggest a widespread ion flux-dependent mechanism in echinoid LR patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study uses a pharmacological approach to investigate the role of ion flux, specifically H+, K+, and Ca2+ transport, in left-right asymmetry establishment in sea urchins.

chunks.text: Adults of Hemicentrotus pulcherrimus were collected and gametes obtained by acetylcholine injection. Compounds were dissolved in artificial seawater (JSW) and fertilized eggs reared to the two-armed pluteus stage. Appropriate concentrations were determined to avoid disrupting normal development. A23187 dose was selected to avoid disrupting gastrulation. DMSO concentration was kept below 0.4%. Statistical analysis used the chi-squared test. For adult rudiment side-specificity, treated larvae were reared for 2 weeks with diatoms. Larvae were observed to determine rudiment formation side. Alkaline phosphatase (APase) histochemistry was performed on prism larvae to assess endoderm differentiation. Whole-mount in situ hybridization was performed as described (Arenas-Mena et al. 2000). Immunohistochemistry was performed on embryos and larvae using antibodies against Xenopus laevis H,K-ATPase subunits. Western blotting was performed on blastula-stage embryos using antibody for the β-subunit.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard methods were employed for animal handling, drug treatments, gene expression analysis, immunohistochemistry, and Western blotting to investigate the role of ion flux in sea urchin left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: HpNot is expressed in the right coelomic pouch of two-armed pluteus larvae, starting asymmetrically at the archenteron tip during the prism stage. HpFoxFQ-like, a homolog of Spfoxc, shows a similar pattern but is preferentially expressed in the left coelomic pouch. These genes serve as right and left-specific asymmetric markers, respectively.
chunks.chunk_summary: HpNot and HpFoxFQ-like exhibit distinct right- and left-sided expression patterns, respectively, in sea urchin larvae, serving as markers for left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: A pharmacological screen using ion channel and gap junction blockers was performed.  DMSO, the vehicle control, slightly reduced right-sided HpNot expression but did not significantly alter laterality.  Most compounds, including amiloride, 9-anthracenecarboxylic acid, 18α-glycyrrhetinic acid, and lanthanum chloride, did not affect HpNot asymmetry.  However, lansoprazole, omeprazole, and SCH28080, all H,K-ATPase blockers, significantly randomized HpNot expression, suggesting a role for H,K-ATPase in LR patterning.  Developmental delay was ruled out by assessing alkaline phosphatase expression.  Omeprazole treatment consistently disrupted sided HpNot expression over time.  The calcium ionophore A23187 also disrupted normal HpNot patterns, dramatically increasing inverted expression.  These data implicate H,K-ATPase and calcium flux in LR asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: H,K-ATPase blockers and a calcium ionophore disrupt the normal sided expression of HpNot, suggesting a role for these ion fluxes in establishing left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: Omeprazole and A23187 were tested on the left-sided marker HpFoxFQ-like. Omeprazole decreased left-sided expression and increased bilateral patterns. A23187 induced reversed expression in some larvae. These results suggest that H,K-ATPase and calcium flux also influence the asymmetry of HpFoxFQ-like expression.
chunks.chunk_summary: Similar to HpNot, the left-sided marker HpFoxFQ-like is also affected by H,K-ATPase blockers and calcium ionophores, indicating a broader role in LR asymmetry establishment.

chunks.text: Omeprazole treatment disrupted the left-sided placement of the adult rudiment in eight-armed pluteus larvae. Some treated larvae showed inverted rudiment placement or no rudiment at all, often with only the vestibule present. This phenotype correlated with disrupted HpNot expression in sibling larvae.  A23187 is already known to disrupt rudiment placement.
chunks.chunk_summary: Omeprazole disrupts the normal left-sided placement of the adult rudiment, further supporting its role in establishing left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: Immunohistochemistry using antibodies against Xenopus H,K-ATPase subunits revealed asymmetric localization in early sea urchin embryos. A single blastomere in 32-cell embryos stained positive, and positive cells remained asymmetrically localized through blastula stages.  Western blots confirmed the presence of a protein of the expected size.  No signal was detected during gastrula stages. This asymmetric localization suggests a role for H,K-ATPase in early LR patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: H,K-ATPase exhibits asymmetric localization in early sea urchin embryos, suggesting its involvement in the initial establishment of left-right asymmetry.

chunks.text: This study demonstrates that H,K-ATPase blockers disrupt LR asymmetric gene expression and adult rudiment placement in sea urchins. H,K-ATPase-like antigens are asymmetrically localized in early embryos. These findings extend previous work and implicate H,K-ATPase as a crucial component of invertebrate LR patterning. The H,K-ATPase is a P-type ATPase with α- and β-subunits. Omeprazole and lansoprazole are benzimidazoles activated in acidic environments, inhibiting H,K-ATPase by reacting with cysteine residues. SCH28080 is a specific antagonist targeting a distinct site. These compounds are effective H,K-ATPase blockers in various organisms. While H,K-ATPase genes are uncharacterized in sea urchins, their functional existence is suggested. Three H,K-ATPase inhibitors with different mechanisms disrupted sidedness of asymmetric markers at physiological concentrations. Other ion channel/pump inhibitors had no effect, indicating that asymmetry is not generally labile in sea urchins. Treatments did not disturb other axes, ruling out secondary effects. H,K-ATPase blockers often induce transposition of HpNot and HpFoxFQ-like signals around the archenteron tip, suggesting a weakened potential for allocating expression sites.
chunks.chunk_summary: H,K-ATPase activity is essential for correct left-right asymmetry in sea urchins, as demonstrated by the disruptive effects of specific inhibitors and the asymmetric localization of H,K-ATPase itself.
